author: sky.cactus
content: <@552133098075193354> I think the problem is that the participants in this room are ignoring one of the axis of technical limitations (disk size) that need to be considered.  We could similarly ignore all CPUs less than 64 cores and IOPS less than 1M and figure out how much of a gas limit we can handle, but that isn't useful information.  We can trivially crank up the gas limit by just cranking the hardware requirements to server class, or DC clusters.  If we don't bound the discussion to some set of agreed hardware, it is a pointless discussion, even technically, I think.

author: sky.cactus
content: Also, things may have changed but 7870 was meant to just be an assertion of current hardware requirements, not meant to imply a target we are shooting for.  <@427491045308235776> can correct me here if I misunderstood or things have changed. author: sky.cactus
content: If you make infinite storage cheap enough, companies will use Ethereum as data backup system.  From this we can assert that there exists a lower bound gas price at which unbounded storage is interested.  It is probably a fairly smooth curve of unknown shape between that and where we are now, but I think it is quite reasonable to assume that the lower gas prices go, the more people will use Ethereum for storage rather than compute.
